docs.lead_paragraph: To Congressional Republicans, the new welfare law is a once-in-a-generation opportunity to replace a 60-year-old system that does not work. To Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the new approach is ''a social risk no sane person would take.'' So which is it? To many welfare experts outside the political rough and tumble, it appears to be both. Americans are fed up with chronic welfare dependence, yet their elected representatives refused to come up with the money to assure a humane transition to a world in which nearly every able-bodied adult must work. The political resolution to that conflict is welfare reform on the cheap. ''It's a big gamble,'' concludes Sheila Zedlewski, director of the Urban Institute's Income and Benefits Policy Center.

headline.main: The Nation's new welfare law is really reform on a shoestring

docs.abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene article on new welfare reform law; notes it fails to provide extra money to wean millions off welfare and instead sharply cuts budget for major assistance programs; questions whether states and localities will act to ease most dolorous consequences; drawing (M)
